nexttext:
Clearly we may also assume that $n\ge 51 (>4^{c_{2}})$.

Before proceeding, we fix some notation: let $R=R_1$, $S=\pi_{1}(G)\le R_2 \wr\hdots\wr R_t$, $r=r_{1}$, and $s=n/r$, so that $S$ is transitive of degree $s$. Also, if one of the $R_j$ for $j\ge 2$, say $R_i$, is an alternating or symmetric group of degree $d$, then set ${\widetilde}{R}:=R_1 \wr R_2 \wr \hdots \wr R_{i-1}$, ${\widetilde}{S}:=\pi_{i-1}(G)\le R_i \wr \hdots \wr R_t$, ${\widetilde}{r}:=\prod_{j<i} r_j$, and ${\widetilde}{s}:=n/{\widetilde}{r}$. Otherwise, set ${\widetilde}{R}:=R$, ${\widetilde}{S}:=S$, ${\widetilde}{r}:=r$, and ${\widetilde}{s}:=s$. Finally, let $C:=c_{0}+2$, where $c_{0}$ is as in Theorem \ref{pyber}. 

We split the remainder of the proof into two cases: suppose first that either $d=r$ or $d \le \max\left\{\log{{\widetilde}{r}},\log{{\widetilde}{s}}\right\}$. Then, from the definitions of $r$, $s$, ${\widetilde}{r}$ and ${\widetilde}{s}$, we see that either $d=r$, or $d\neq r$ and one of the following holds \begin{enumerate}[(a)]
\item $d\le \log{{\widetilde}{s}}\le \log{s}$, or;
\item $\log{{\widetilde}{s}}<d\le \log{{\widetilde}{r}}$. In this case, either ${\widetilde}{r}\le s$, in which case $d\le \log{s}$; or ${\widetilde}{r}>s$, in which case $r>{\widetilde}{s}$. Since either ${\widetilde}{s}>d$ or $d=c_{2}$ and $s={\widetilde}{s}=2$ (recall that $d\neq r$), it follows that ${\widetilde}{r}>s$ implies that $r>d$.
\end{enumerate}
Now, using Proposition \ref{pq1}, there exists a constant $b_{1}'$ such that
Combining this with Theorems \ref{TransTheoremCor1} and \ref{pyber}, and the inequality at (3.1), we get
prevtext:
Clearly we may also assume that $n\ge 51 (>4^{c_{2}})$.

Before proceeding, we fix some notation: let $R=R_1$, $S=\pi_{1}(G)\le R_2 \wr\hdots\wr R_t$, $r=r_{1}$, and $s=n/r$, so that $S$ is transitive of degree $s$. Also, if one of the $R_j$ for $j\ge 2$, say $R_i$, is an alternating or symmetric group of degree $d$, then set ${\widetilde}{R}:=R_1 \wr R_2 \wr \hdots \wr R_{i-1}$, ${\widetilde}{S}:=\pi_{i-1}(G)\le R_i \wr \hdots \wr R_t$, ${\widetilde}{r}:=\prod_{j<i} r_j$, and ${\widetilde}{s}:=n/{\widetilde}{r}$. Otherwise, set ${\widetilde}{R}:=R$, ${\widetilde}{S}:=S$, ${\widetilde}{r}:=r$, and ${\widetilde}{s}:=s$. Finally, let $C:=c_{0}+2$, where $c_{0}$ is as in Theorem \ref{pyber}. 

We split the remainder of the proof into two cases: suppose first that either $d=r$ or $d \le \max\left\{\log{{\widetilde}{r}},\log{{\widetilde}{s}}\right\}$. Then, from the definitions of $r$, $s$, ${\widetilde}{r}$ and ${\widetilde}{s}$, we see that either $d=r$, or $d\neq r$ and one of the following holds \begin{enumerate}[(a)]
\item $d\le \log{{\widetilde}{s}}\le \log{s}$, or;
\item $\log{{\widetilde}{s}}<d\le \log{{\widetilde}{r}}$. In this case, either ${\widetilde}{r}\le s$, in which case $d\le \log{s}$; or ${\widetilde}{r}>s$, in which case $r>{\widetilde}{s}$. Since either ${\widetilde}{s}>d$ or $d=c_{2}$ and $s={\widetilde}{s}=2$ (recall that $d\neq r$), it follows that ${\widetilde}{r}>s$ implies that $r>d$.
\end{enumerate}
Now, using Proposition \ref{pq1}, there exists a constant $b_{1}'$ such that
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="d(G)\leq\frac{a(R)b_{1}^{\prime}s}{\sqrt{\log{s}}}+d(\pi(G))" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>G</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>R</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>b</mi><mn>1</mn><mo>′</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow><msqrt><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow></msqrt></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>G</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Since either $d\le r$ or $d\le \log{s}$ (see (a),(b) and the preceding comment above), this goes to $0$ if either $r$ or $s$ is increasing, which gives us what we need.

Finally, assume that $d>\max\left\{\log{{\widetilde}{r}},\log{{\widetilde}{s}}\right\}$, and that $d\neq r$. Since $n={\widetilde}{r}{\widetilde}{s}$ and $n>4^{c_{2}}$, we have $d>c_{2}$, so one of the $R_j$ for $j\ge 2$, must be an alternating or symmetric group of degree $d$. Thus, by definition we have ${\widetilde}{R}:=R_1 \wr R_2 \wr \hdots \wr R_{i-1}$, ${\widetilde}{S}:=\pi_{i-1}(G)\le R_i \wr \hdots \wr R_t$, and ${\widetilde}{r}:=\prod_{j<i} r_j$. Then, by Lemma \ref{MainLemma} and Theorems \ref{TransTheoremCor1} and \ref{TransCompLength}, we have
